events.target_title: Screenlock does not turn off screen, shows cursor

note.body:
Same issue on Ubuntu 19.04 (GNOME 3.32.1) with NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 6GB/PCIe/SSE2. There is no way for a computer to turn off the screen when the monitor is connected via DisplayPort. The monitor turns off just fine via HDMI.

Update 1: Just installed Kubuntu 19.04 (KDE 5.15.4) and the exact same issue appears. So this is not a GNOME problem, it goes further.

Update 2: Found the solution here https://devtalk.nvidia.com/default/topic/791786/linux/dpms-not-working-on-gtx980-with-displayport-connection/3. The only thing you have to do is to add the following line for Screen and Monitor section in xorg.conf: 
Option "HardDPMS" "true"

I couldn't get it to work with my own file, so I just changed the existing 10-nvidia.conf in /usr/share/X11/xorg.conf.d/. Because you need to add some parameters to identify those devices, it's easier to copy the configuration for your screen and monitor from Nvidia X Server settings (X Server Display Configuration -> Save to X Configuration file -> Show preview).

note.body:
@3v1n0 I'm not really sure that I did understand what you mean by symbols.
Whoever, I did extract a new dump with the following valgrind arguments:
```
env G_SLICE=always-malloc \
> valgrind --log-file=gnome-shell.valgrind \
> --leak-check=full \
> --show-leak-kinds=all \
> --track-origins=yes \
> --verbose \
> gnome-shell
```

[gnome-shell.valgrind](/uploads/1d37ba788152f43854922a6b3710bf6b/gnome-shell.valgrind)

Anyway, appreciate your assistance. If this isn't still whats needed do let me know and I'll get you the needed information.

events.target_title: gnome-shell 3.32.1 memory leak

note.body:
Sorry for the late return on this guys. Finally, I've been able to allocate a bit of my spare time on this, and after understanding more about valgrind, I have installed the following debug symbols: * ~~libmutter-4-0-dbgsym (has requested by @3v1n0)~~ * libgtk-3-0-dbgsym (had a lot of lost bytes pointing to this library) * ~~gnome-shell-dbgsym (due to missing debug symbols for ligobject-2-0, which solved after installing this one)~~ Unfortunately, the dump will still miss the debug symbol for libgio-2-0 because I didn't find any available. [gnome-shell2.valgrind](/uploads/7a72530556847f3e88cfea50e74d1798/gnome-shell2.valgrind)
[gnome-shell.pmap](/uploads/f6ba9a759efec1517a0ea06a75200f0e/gnome-shell.pmap) Edit: I did find the libgio3.0-cil-dbgsym and attached a new dump from Valgrind. Edit2: Without any excuse, I didn't take a look till the end of the Valgrind dump, so there were a few debug symbols still missing.
Taking this into consideration I've managed to get all the other missing ones, except for: * libmutter-cogl-4.so - libmutter-4-0-dbgsym and mutter-dbgsym installed * gnome-shell - gnome-shell-dbgsym installed * libdconfsettings.so - libglib2.0-0-dbgsym installed * ld-2.29.so - libc6-dbg and libc6-i386-dbgsym installed [gnome-shell3.valgrind](/uploads/c6c8c32f0f37bef194ec8bcd586538c7/gnome-shell3.valgrind)

note.body:
I've been playing with the clipboard test tool and while it successfully creates a file for some of the other formats there, its output is weirdly distorted.

Example:
![image](/uploads/11ae13d11c99c3509333ac68ea9156b1/image.png)
![image](/uploads/fd18af28f709c1766d6352a4bcca4e6f/image.png)
pasted via image/bmp.

I have no clue how or why but it looks like bytes are being deterministically, but at seemingly random locations, inserted into the bitmap by something GTK is doing. cliptool reports the original bitmap as having size 67854 bytes, but the file produced by gimp's clipboard debugger is 67949 bytes.  Maybe there's some sort of chunked buffer reading mechanism that has an off by one error?

Oh my god. It's doing newline conversion on the buffer (/n -> /r/n).

[orig.txt](/uploads/2a35f60e58ecf80d7e90035c87e91007/orig.txt)
[file.txt](/uploads/761b28a010b98593fa9bea917c3839b0/file.txt)

events.target_title: Cannot paste images into GIMP copied from Telegram.

note.body:
Without looking at any of the code, I'm inclined to suspect the newline conversion is happening when the clipboard tool writes the file, not when it reads the buffer from the clipboard.

Still, it's curious that for some reason, it produces no output for PNG files.

Looking at its output when I copy something from mspaint, it looks like it's converting CF_DIB into image/bmp, which there is already an entry for. Maybe the conflict is causing the issue.

Alternatively, maybe it builds the image/bmp entry from both CF_DIB and also CF_METAFILEPICT, which is absent in the telegram clipboard data. Perhaps this is causing the issue.

I'll play around with it and see if I can trick it into working.

events.target_title: Regression: Valid regexp no longer matches specific strings
Regression: Valid regexp no longer matches specific strings

note.body:
Well, I can't reproduce the intermittent success, it always fails for me whether I run ./testRegexp in the toplevel directory or in the .libs subdirectory. However it should not be unexpected that this can give different results, since the actual executable in the .libs directory is dynamically linked, and thus will typically run with the libxml2 library that is installed in the OS. E.g. in my test install of 2.9.9 on FreeBSD:
```
$ pwd
/tmp/libxml2-2.9.9/.libs
$ ldd testRegexp 
testRegexp:
        libxml2.so.2 => /usr/local/lib/libxml2.so.2 (0x800249000)
        libthr.so.3 => /lib/libthr.so.3 (0x8003df000)
        libz.so.6 => /lib/libz.so.6 (0x80040a000)
        liblzma.so.5 => /usr/lib/liblzma.so.5 (0x800424000)
        libm.so.5 => /lib/libm.so.5 (0x80044f000)
        libc.so.7 => /lib/libc.so.7 (0x800481000)
```
Where /usr/local/lib/libxml2.so.2 is actually the OS' 2.9.7 version. The testRegexp in the toplevel directory on the other hand is a shell script, that among other things sets up LD_LIBRARY_PATH to point into the build tree before running the executable:
```
$ pwd
/tmp/libxml2-2.9.9
$ sh -x ./testRegexp '( (a|bc{0,2})){0,2} d' ' b d'
...
+ LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/tmp/libxml2-2.9.9/.libs
+ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH
...
+ exec /tmp/libxml2-2.9.9/.libs/testRegexp '( (a|bc{0,2})){0,2} d' ' b d'
Testing ( (a|bc{0,2})){0,2} d:
 b d: Fail
```
So, to make sure you are actually testing the version you've built, you should always run from the toplevel directory. Still, your observation of intermittent success is interesting - the only reason I can think of is that a variable that isn't explicitly initialized is used somewhere in the code. This could cause not only random success/failure for a given version, but also persistent success - or persistent failure - for another version. depending on how the variable gets the value it actually has.

events.target_title: Regression: Valid regexp no longer matches specific strings

note.body:
Hm, even though it seems "valgrind" is regularly used on the libxml2 build, I decided to have a go at it myself - it has proven invaluable to find (among others) used-when-uninitialized bugs in my own code. I ran it on the testRegexp executable (after having made sure that it would use the right version of the library):
```
valgrind --tool=memcheck ./testRegexp '( (a|bc{0,2})){0,2} d' ' b d' 
```
But there was no "depends on uninitialised value(s)" report. Just to make sure, I actually *introduced* a used-when-uninitialized bug in the related code:
```
--- xmlregexp.c.ORIG    2017-10-26 09:54:40.000000000 +0200
+++ xmlregexp.c 2019-06-10 12:34:59.873363372 +0200
@@ -1544,7 +1544,7 @@
 xmlFAGenerateTransitions(xmlRegParserCtxtPtr ctxt, xmlRegStatePtr from,
                         xmlRegStatePtr to, xmlRegAtomPtr atom) {
     xmlRegStatePtr end;
-    int nullable = 0;
+    int nullable;
 
     if (atom == NULL) {
        ERROR("genrate transition: atom == NULL");
@@ -1733,6 +1733,7 @@
     }
     if ((atom->quant == XML_REGEXP_QUANT_RANGE) &&
         (atom->min == 0) && (atom->max > 0)) {
+       fprintf(stderr, "setting nullable\n");
        nullable = 1;
        atom->min = 1;
         if (atom->max == 1)
@@ -1755,6 +1756,7 @@
            xmlRegStateAddTrans(ctxt, to, atom, to, -1, -1);
            break;
        case XML_REGEXP_QUANT_RANGE:
+           fprintf(stderr, "using nullable\n");
            if (nullable)
                xmlFAGenerateEpsilonTransition(ctxt, from, to);
            break;
```
IME, this should elicit a "may be used uninitialized" diagnostic already at compile time, but it did not. And valgrind still doesn't give a "depends on uninitialised value(s)" report, even when I choose a different test that clearly doesn't have a setting of "nullable" in the code path:
```
$ valgrind --tool=memcheck ./testRegexp 'a{1,2}' a
==24772== Memcheck, a memory error detector
==24772== Copyright (C) 2002-2017, and GNU GPL'd, by Julian Seward et al.
==24772== Using Valgrind-3.13.0 and LibVEX; rerun with -h for copyright info
==24772== Command: ./testRegexp a{1,2} a
==24772== 
Testing a{1,2}:
using nullable
a: Ok
==24772== 
==24772== HEAP SUMMARY:
==24772==     in use at exit: 40 bytes in 1 blocks
==24772==   total heap usage: 16 allocs, 15 frees, 2,095 bytes allocated
==24772== 
==24772== LEAK SUMMARY:
==24772==    definitely lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==24772==    indirectly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==24772==      possibly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==24772==    still reachable: 40 bytes in 1 blocks
==24772==         suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==24772== Rerun with --leak-check=full to see details of leaked memory
==24772== 
==24772== For counts of detected and suppressed errors, rerun with: -v
==24772== ERROR SUMMARY: 0 errors from 0 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0)
```
I have to say that I find these results very strange, thinking that I must be missing something, but I can't see what that might be. In any case, at this point I have to say that the fact that valgrind doesn't report any use of uninitialized variables can't be taken as evidence that there isn't any.

events.target_title: Replace totally unnecessary UTF-8 colons by real ones.

note.body:
Another +1 from me - I find it quite appalling that nothing has been done for this problem in a year's time. Note that you don't need to have a "broken" locale to trigger the crash, unless you want to consider the default "C"/POSIX locale as broken - you *must* have a locale that supports UTF-8 (or, theoretically, some other encoding of Unicode) to avoid it. If you really want that to be a requirement, Pan should check it and exit with a proper error message if it isn't fulfilled.

Also, I don't actually think this is a bug in g_locale_from_utf8 - what is it supposed to do with those Unicode RATIO characters if the current locale doesn't support Unicode/UTF-8? There's no technical basis for converting them to ascii Colon just because they "look similar".

I tried to have a look at @tmiasko's branch, but it seems it is gone. I also don't see the point in replacing the g_locale_from_utf8 calls with g_date_time_format just because the latter possibly used to fail with Unicode characters and possibly doesn't anymore: it is an alternative to standard libc strftime(), but that's not where the problem is. As far as I can see, g_date_time_format will not convert UTF-8 in the format string to something else, so it would be equivalent to just removing the g_locale_from_utf8 calls and use the format strings as-is with strftime() - which may actually be an alternate solution. Does anyone know why they are there in the first place?

events.target_title: EULA confirmation support
Improving FITS file / astrophotography support in GIMP
Improving FITS file / astrophotography support in GIMP

note.body:
I am a developer, currently I'm writing software on the creation side (building a digital microscope, which is _very_ similar to astrophotography except technically I'm looking down the tube from the wrong end :-) but I've also implemented chunks of FITS HCOMPRESS in Javascript/WebGL shaders so I'm familiar with some of the internals. 

I've just had a look through the source code... seems to me that the basic issue is the plugin is using the "fitsrw 0.12" library which was last modified 25-Aug-06. I think it's a testament to the stability of FITS that it's still working at all!

In contrast, "cfitsio" (the official NASA library) is still under active development and version 3.47 was released last month.

I would guess that it's not a hard task to pull out the old library and drop in the new. All the same underlying features will be equivalent, just the names and parameters of the function call will have changed a bit. However, that's only a small part of the 1200 lines of code for the plug-in, most of which is doing GIMP-specific stuff. 

In a basic sense, both libraries work by going "file_open()" which pulls in a few headers and metadata blocks that list the embedded images, and then "load_image(file, id, buffer)" which reads each image into a memory block. In fact the old code seems to read the data pixel by pixel, whereas cfitsio has a "fits_read_pix()" function which does an entire memory-buffer at a time, so the new library would likely be easier to use and significantly faster. All the decompression is handled transparently behind-the-scenes. 

In fact cfitsio seems to have _more_ in common with the way that GIMP works... GIMP 'tiles' large images, and so does the cfitsio image compressor. You can ask for a tile of the image and cfitsio will efficiently load in just the required block (actually, mmap it directly from disk) without having to buffer the entire image in memory or scan the file.

Writing out images is much the same, if you want to keep all the existing functionality. Open a file, append some metadata, write the image chunks by passing memory blocks, job done.

Therefore, updating the plugin is more about knowing how GIMP works than knowing FITS. Especially if it comes to dealing with layer groups and dialog options. I've never worked on the GIMP codebase, and would likely screw more things up than I would fix. I don't have the development environment set up (never a trivial task) or the relationships with the dev team to get my changes pulled into the main branch. I'm happy to advise, but there's better people than me for that too... I'm sure the NASA HEASARC people would love to see GIMP support improved. Dr William Pence is the main developer of cfitsio and encouraging the widespread use of FITS is probably his full-time job: https://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/bios/pence.html

The biggest issue with FITS is that it's SO flexible that I don't know half the ways it's used by the professional astro community, just the fun ways that I've used it. I don't know what most of the metadata tags are supposed to do, for example.

Huh... I just noticed while looking through the code that the old library actually DOES handle RGB images (and RGBA), but in a 'matrix reversed way'. If you give it a 3D array shaped [100,100,3] it assumes it's a 100x100 array of RGB tuples... whereas the modern style seems to be to shape it [3,100,100] as three 'planes' of image data. (or as three separate [100x100] HDU's because that can be compressed more efficiently, and each plane can have it's own metadata.)

However if it comes down to it and no-one else is prepared to update the plug-in, I will have a look at it after I work through my existing to-do list. But I honestly think it would end up sucking more time out of the core developers doing bugfixes to the things I broke than it would to #include a different library, swap over a few function calls, and tweak it into a more modern idiom. 

The last update of the plugin was `16-Aug-06` and I'll bet that half the GIMP calls it makes have been deprecated for shiny new GEGL interfaces. Someone who's already far up the learning curve of GIMP internals is going to be much better at the job than I would be, and the patches would be much more likely to make it into the main branch quickly.

events.target_title: Wide-format scanners: Scan area not centered when scanning with feeder

note.body:
See also [utsushi/utsushi#68](https://gitlab.com/utsushi/utsushi/issues/68).

The issue is really with Simple Scan ~~dumbing down~~ simplifying the user interface by mapping backend options to its preferred view of the world.  That is, it takes away the full set of options provided by the various backends in order to provide a unified user experience.  No matter what scanner you use, the interface doesn't change.
That is not inherently bad, but it does take away control of full set of capabilities of the user's device.

In this case, Simple Scan needs to become aware of a few "uncommon" backend options.

\# The situation for third-party SANE backends such as `epkowa` and `utsushi`, is worse than that for the ones included in `sane-backends`.

BTW, I don't think the `epson2` backend supports this in the first place.  The `epkowa` and `utsushi` backends probably do.

events.target_title: Wide-format scanners: Scan area not centered when scanning with feeder

note.body:
Yes, but "simply" might be a bit of an over-statement considering that Simple Scan needs to "swipe these details under the rug" for *all* backends, whether third-party or not.

Just the `sane-backends` is already a list of 94 backends :scream_cat: and I have **no** idea how many third-party ones there are.

Hi,

Thanks for having written this down here.
Trying to grasp the Nepomuk ontology situation indeed left me very confused.  
For the purpose of representing emails in linked data I got looking into Nepomuk. I knew that the Nepomuk project has been dead for many years and believed that [http://oscaf.sourceforge.net/](http://oscaf.sourceforge.net/) must be a mirror of the latest documentation.
After some more searching I was happy to find [https://developer.gnome.org/ontology/2.0/](https://developer.gnome.org/ontology/2.0/) and for a moment thought that the project must have been brought back to life by Gnome and even extended/improved upon. Some classes, such as [nmo:MailFolder](https://developer.gnome.org/ontology/2.0/nmo-MailFolder.html) can be found in the Gnome ontology documentation, but not on the mirror site, others have been removed over time ([8b525290](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/tracker/commit/8b5252904611d10b89632539c18483ac83e29424)). While browsing this repository I now see that [the relevant comments are there](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/tracker/blob/master/src/ontologies/nepomuk/34-nmo.ontology#L99), but it indeed would be a great improvement to specify in the documentation site which parts of the ontology are Nepomuk, which parts are extended (these should be under different domain, no?) and which parts are legacy. 
Given some some extra info I maybe could help out with this?

Michaël

events.target_title: GDK_SCALE=X is not respected when using "gio open"

note.body:
When I invoke `gio open XXX` from my **terminal**, I expect that the script will preserve my environment variables.  This is a convention in the UNIX world. When it does not behave like this, it surprises the users and the problem is hard to debug (I spend several hours debugging this problem and I only know the root cause after Philip's answers). I understand that in gnome, it might be reasonable to discourage the usage of environment variables to configure things, but there are also other simple tools that are expected to be invoked from terminal and environment variable makes perfect senses for them.

The problem of `gio open --key` is that people use `gio open` from `xdg-open`, which is hard to add more parameters.  All in all, I really don't see why the environment variables shouldn't be preserved in `gio-open` in the first place.

events.target_title: Feature Request - Open Minimized

note.body:
Andre,

Firstly, thank you for the prompt response, and I am very sorry that my original post was not sufficiently clear.

To answer your questions in reverse order: yes, I find that if I have a Calendar reminder set in GNOME Calendar, but Calendar is not running, then I do not see a reminder. I can configure my Cinnamon desktop to automatically launch Calendar for me, but when I do that it simply starts up in full-screen mode, filling my entire desktop. What I would like to do is have Calendar launch so that it is active, but running in minimized form. 

I am using Linux Mint 19.2, Tina, which is supplied with Cinnamon 4.2 on top of GNU/Linux 4.15 and built on the Ubuntu 18.04 package base.

The Cinnamon desktop [which started out as a GNOME skin but is now a complete desktop in its own right] has a layout model somewhat similar to Microsoft Windows 7, in that it has a retractable docking strip that can be configured to appear along the edge of a monitor/display (the "task bar") to show running applications. By default, this "task bar" has a small area which appears in the lower right corner of a monitor and which includes a local system clock and "iconised" representations of various key tasks and services (such as wired/wireless network status, bluetooth status, removable drive status, and applications that are running in background, or minimized).

I was wondering/hoping if you might configure a command-line option to Calendar that could be specified in the launch command instruction for a desktop, so that Calendar loads, launches but runs minimized or in the background please?

This would allow Calendar to issue alerts for previously scheduled diary appointments, since it does seem to need to be active and running in order for these to trigger a reminder.

I've looked through documentation but can't see any other way to achieve this... Happy to be corrected if I've missed something, but that, in a nutshell, was what I was hoping for.

Thank you.

events.target_title: Windows behaviour seems to be incorrect with respect to Desktop settings on focus/auto raise.
Windows behaviour seems to be incorrect with respect to Desktop settings on focus/auto raise.

note.body:
Fedora 30

XFCE  4.12

Evince 3.32.0

Just to be clear on what I mean by broken and expected behaviour (not following windows manager settings):

*Expected behaviour == not change z-order (window not raise it self), unless title or window frame clicked.*

*Broken behaviour == changing Z order (window raises it self), when client area of window clicked.*

I had noticed this a while back, but never got round to reporting it.  By the way this behaviour is also shown by google-chrome and Midori browsers.

Have tried geany (which behaves as expected) and eog (which behaves like Evince).

It seems to be any app that uses the new fangled GUI of not having a proper title window with client area.  This is really a step backwards in usability, the most elegant/useful part of Linux (X) desktops is to have  overlapping windows with ability to layer them and have the desktop keep that z-order unless the user changes it by requesting a window into foreground.  Th new approach makes things behave like in the MS windows (and MacOS) world, which is broken (the way X desktops - FVWM, OLVWM etc have treated window layering and focus (lazy, follow mouse)) has always been superior).

1) No one develop absolutely ALL RAWs (and anyway not all at the same time). So even if we export JPG with the good filename, there are many RAW not developed and so Shotwell will continue to force their ugly JPG. Also, like many others : first I put my pics in all right folders, and *then* I sort, decide which ones I will delete, develop, etc.

2) The last question is a bit snaky. :smile:  : I use Shotwell because I think **it is** the best software to organize all my thousands pics, with the best ergonomy, with the best integration while I'm on Gnome, with the ability to save meta-data inside JPG, etc, etc, etc. Shotwell **does** meet all my needs. But it's NOT the good software to develop RAW, developing is a human task, and **I don't want any automatic massive thing**! And yes : I want all my RAWs to be stored in the same folders : it would be totally absurd to maintain a parallel folder tree with all the same hundred of folders only for RAW, I have just one Photos folder with one tree.

So please, just let us disabling RAW in Shotwell and don't take them in account at all.

GtkIMContextSimple ignores XCompose include directives
GtkIMContextSimple ignores XCompose include directives

note.body:
The documentation is definitely being misleading right now so I agree that rewriting it might be a good idea.

If we are to stick to a more limited interpretation of compose behavior, I think it would be also a good idea to clarify how the xcompose file deals withs with locale-specific compose rules (aka the pt-BR ç problem)

In the original XCompose behavior, a personal .XCompose file would completely disable the pre-defined compose rules from the system. If you wanted to keep those you had to add a `include "%L"` directive.

On the other hand, GTK seems to always have the "en_US" compose sequences activated, as if the XCompose file had an implicit `include "/usr/share/X11/locale/en_US.UTF-8/Compose"`. Perhaps it would be possible to change GTK's behavior to also always include the locale-specific compose rules?

I haven't figured out how everything works yet, but this line in gtkimcontextsimple.c seems to be one of the reasons why the locale-specific rules are being left out:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/master/gtk/gtkimcontextsimple.c#L192

Nautilus gets laggy when using custom user-dirs
Nautilus gets laggy when using custom user-dirs

note.body:
I'm testing with latest code from git
```
5a4536877 (HEAD -> master, origin/master) Update Greek translation
b282a1a93 triage-policies: Don't repeat untriaged issues
7605b17b2 meson.build: Disable GLib deprecation warnings
e76cfc998 location-entry: Allow white space padding
a4e46a970 Update Hungarian translation
9c5ce0dd1 files-view: Stop leaking context menus
0c769dd6c files-view: Use g_autoptr for GtkBuilder
55f075330 files-view: Stop sinking ref for GMenu instances
```
I mapped `XDG_DOWNLOAD_DIR`, `XDG_TEMPLATES_DIR`, `XDG_PUBLICSHARE_DIR`, ... to `$HOME/data` which contains a lot of files (downloaded files). I played a little bit with Nautilus code and found an interesting thing:

file `src/nautilus-files-view.c` line no.[`3031`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/blob/master/src/nautilus-files-view.c#L3031)
I tried to hijack the file to print file path when `add_directory_to_templates_directory_list` got called, I saw that this APIs had called all the time even if I was doing nothing, please check [nautilus-run-log.txt](/uploads/f2589a07e4c819a69e45b96be04f3e88/nautilus-run-log.txt). Surprisingly, all files in our `$HOME/data` was there, in the log.
```C
static void
add_directory_to_templates_directory_list (NautilusFilesView *view,
                                           NautilusDirectory *directory)
{
    NautilusFilesViewPrivate *priv;

    priv = nautilus_files_view_get_instance_private (view);

    // to see what really added to templates_directory_list
    printf("----------->%s\n", g_file_get_path(nautilus_directory_get_location(directory)));

    add_directory_to_directory_list (view, directory,
                                     &priv->templates_directory_list,
                                     G_CALLBACK (templates_added_or_changed_callback));
}
```

I did one test which I removed `$HOME/data`, performance come back to normal (no lag, no freeze).
I also tried to modify all `XDG_*_DIR` variables except `XDG_TEMPLATES_DIR`, performance was not down (no lag, no freeze).

It seem there is different handling for `XDG_TEMPLATES_DIR` compares to the others where with `XDG_TEMPLATES_DIR`, Nautilus scans all files in mapping folder in order to add to `templates_directory_list` which causes performance down (laggy).

Could you please check if it is intentional or not?
Thanks.

events.target_title: Changes to support windows
gnome-calculator 3.33.2 port to Windows

note.body:
Alright, I have done this.  See: https://gitlab.gnome.org/bastidest/gnome-calculator/merge_requests/1

Basically, what I did was used the GetLocaleInfo Win32 API function.  The code is new a new file, /lib/nlswindows.c which I added to the build system if using meson in Windows and I updated the vala files. 

In addition, I also had to add a dependency upon "gmp" which both libmpc and mpfr depend upon.  Otherwise, it causes a link error in Windows MSYS2 GCC compiler for MINGW-W64.  Most of this is based upon work on a MINGW package at https://github.com/msys2/MINGW-packages/tree/master/mingw-w64-gnome-calculator .  The ultimate idea is to get this to build right out of the box.

Alright, I think this has a little more success at least on both Linux and Windows.  There could other build problems with Linux but I can't comment.  I do know I did sucede with one Linux distro.

The approach I took was to define a WINDOWS define for vala if building for Windows and the valas will generate different code.  For some reason IF POSIX didn't work as I had wanted.

events.target_title: gnome-calculator 3.33.2 port to Windows

note.body:
Alright, I did make an update at https://gitlab.gnome.org/jpmugaas/gnome-calculator/tree/windows-fixes which I hope will satisfy.  I had a little problem earlier with Vala not doing what I expected with the POSIX define under Linux. So I had the meson.build add a WINDOWS define to vala and then when activated, it will output the correct Windows code instead of the Linux nls code.

This is unusual because of this is one task that can differ significantly depending upon platform.

Problem being that browser vendors probably aren't interested in doing much integration with Linux.

>  That is a web specification for browser implementors, and not how "native" notifications work. Browsers use the native platform notification API to implement the web specification.

I'm sure DragoCubed understands that but browser vendors surely wouldn't just half bake that implementation, right?

> Now if this is something browser vendors are interested in using, then I think we can reconsider that change.

Their point was that Windows 10 does support images and app icons and that browser vendors make use of that. That's why browser vendors are interested in it.

note.body:
Hi @antoniof ,

I've read there is a "legacy" option that can be set to make ZFS look at fstab. I attempted to set the mountpoint to legacy just as a test, but I wasn't able to get my dataset to mount using that method. 

I don't really feel like this would be a viable option for me.  Typically, ZFS just handles the mount of its datasets automatically. It seems like it is defeating some of the convenience of ZFS to have to add an additional entry to fstab in order to make things look right in nautilus.

Probably the average desktop user using ZFS would not expect to have to do this.

Thanks.

events.target_title: No way to remove zfs mounts from sidebar when mounts occur in user Home folder

note.body:
Antonio,

My intuition from this just as an everyday user is that items in the sidebar with an eject button would be portable drives like usb thumb drives and external hard drives. Their temporary nature is underlined by the eject button that appears to their right. I would expect to be able to click on the eject button and physically remove from the computer. 

I think of ZFS volumes and datasets as being in a different category all together.

events.target_title: No way to remove zfs mounts from sidebar when mounts occur in user Home folder

note.body:
@antoniof While it would be technically possible to use ZFS in a portable drive, I think it would be an edge case. To use zfs as a portable drive, the drive would have to be attached to the computer, the zpool would then need to be imported with `sudo zpool import {POOL_NAME}`. Then to remove the device, the command `sudo zpool export {POOL_NAME}` would need to be issued to properly prepare the filesystem to be used on another system. My impression is that the majority of use cases for zfs are multi-disk raid arrays and mirror sets that just stay with the computer they're on. That's certainly how I use it. 

I like the idea this info in the "+Other Locations" section if that would be a simple solution.  My main objection to the sidebar is the clutter. It makes it difficult to locate my bookmarks and to find _actual_ removable drives that I'm using.

note.body:
I've a found a work-around which may give a clue. Most likely, there exist race conditions on initializing everything at the first run.

I renamed **/usr/local/lib/babl-0.1/16bit.so**, and started **gimp**, it loaded everything, I quit, renamed that **16bit.so** back to original name. Now the issue has gone, **gimp** perfectly works.

Only had a minor issue with undefined symbols from cairo-gobject and libcroco when compiling my static project. Solved it by manually adding these libs to the linker command. I've also just tried to configure this. I have the same intended setup as Steve, a multi-seat machine with different auto login users per seat.

Looks like this is the commit that pulled the functionality out:

```
$ git log -S "gdm_slave_parse_enriched_login"
commit 48f35210656c6f80052dce598d648bd17101a1cc
Author: Ray Strode <rstrode@redhat.com>
Date:   Wed Feb 11 01:51:07 2015 -0500

    slave: drop the slaves
    
    At this point the slaves do nothing useful, so we can
    get rid of them.
    
    https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=744764
```

events.target_title: custom.conf, AutomaticLogin script not working

note.body:
I've switched to lightdm on Ubuntu 18.04 to work around this:

* sudo apt install lightdm
* switch default to lightdm when prompted
* edit /etc/lightdm/lightdm.conf.d/10-autologin.conf

~~~
[Seat:seat0]
autologin-user=steam-user1

[Seat:seat1]
autologin-user=steam-user2
~~~

* Reboot
